The Review. Jamie's Italian

If only all the food had tasted as tantalising as it looked

The Review. Ambiente

Ambiente Tapas lives up to its billing as a contemporary Spanish eatery

The Review. Oshibi

By James Bithell

Richard Rhodes reviews the Asian cuisine of Oshibi restaurant (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Richard Rhodes)

The Review. La Vecchia Scuola

As Italian restaurant addicts, the imposing white facade, pillars, and appearance of happy diners sipping red wine through the windows convinced us that this would be a safe bet

The Review. Loch Fyne

Liz Cahill takes a trip to the seafood restaurant, Loch Fyne

The Review. Harkers Roast

It's Sunday afternoon. Until now, the thought of eating anything has been a mere fantasy.

The Review: The Loop Bar & Grill

A joke becomes obvious on arrival: this place isn't in the loop

Pub: Three Legged Mare

As I sat in the <strong>Three Legged Mare</strong>, my friends around me, listening to a pianist play a Lady Gaga medley it struck me that there is a fatal flaw to pub reviews...

Pub: Brigantes

A slight break from the traditional here as the pub review looks at a "bar and brasserie". In my defence <strong>Brigantes</strong> is able to offer one of the best selection of ales in York and as such qualifies

Pub: The Tam O' Shanter

Being a pub reviewer is pretty fun, as jobs go. You don't have to do much work and even when you do, the most taxing it gets when you just have to drain that last pint. Having said that since I've been touring the pubs I've been waiting to give a scathing review, to channel my inner A. A. Gill but, alas, in York, it's just not possible (Thumbnail credit Photo: Jason Lozier)

Cafe No. 8

What to do as a student on a Saturday night? 'Salvation, Tokyo and Ziggy's' are full of the over thirties/lonely hearts and apparently no one (particularly YUSU) likes Gallery anymore

Asia Gourmet

Looks can be deceiving and I sincerely hoped so when I stood outside Asia Gourmet on a warm spring evening

Thirteen Thirty One

Certainly, tread very carefully when entering an establishment that peddles food by day and drunkenness by night

Khao San

Khao San Rd, deemed the 'new Thai restaurant on the block', immediately grabbed my attention. I couldn't wait to go in and take a look around, especially as Thai is one of my favourite cuisines

Melton's

When I say I have eaten at Melton's, everyone seems to automatically assume I am talking about its sister restaurant Melton's Too in Walmgate (Thumbnail credit Photo: Jason Lozier)

The Blue Bicycle

Although The Blue Bicycle is a firm spot on the list of fine dining resturants in York, I had heard mixed reviews (Thumbnail credit Photo: Sam Newsome)

Goji Vegetarian Cafe and Deli

Inside Goji is small and quirky, with entertaining views of another, much better looking cafe, a sex shop, and an assortment of charity shops and old people to keep you occupied.

Mason's Bistro Bar

If you need to commemorate the end of exams and feel you deserve a touch more class then a night of debauchery in Ziggy's and a Yummy Chicken to celebrate, then Mason's Mediterranean bistro is for you.

The Last Drop Inn

Assuming they would have the inside track, I approached two policemen and asked which of York's three thousand and twelve pubs they recomended. By the time they had replied, I was in too deep. It would now be illegal for me not to visit the Last Drop Inn, property of the York Brewery, on Colliergate.

J Baker's Bistro Moderne

Jeff Baker was the first Leeds chef ever to hold a Michelin star. In 2005 he was named Yorkshire Chef of the Year, and both Jeff and his first solo project, J. Baker's, score highly in UK gastro-polls.

Red Chilli

I have had too many distressing encounters with lukewarm bowls of viscous compost; I am harrowed by apparitions of diced sludge; I have had surfeit of cashew nut. If Red Chilli might have changed my mind, it didn't.

Ha! Ha! Bar & Canteen

Ha! Ha! prides itself on good bistro-type food, but if you go for a drink the chances are you won't leave with fond memories.

Buzz Bar (refurbished)

<strong>Location:</strong> Swinegate <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * * Tokyo, you may not know, is now the world's haute cuisine capital. Its restaurants have 191 Michelin stars between them compared to Paris's 97 and New York's 54.

Which Sweeties?

Gosh, isn't it a long time since you skipped off to the sweetie shop in the first flush of youth, with a feverish glint in your eye! Some readers may have fond memories of a generic Woolworth's pic 'n' mix counter feeding their childhood sugar-based fantasies, others may have had their confectionary dispensed by a kindly old tweed-clad gentleman who wore special gloves and had a slightly creepy smile...

Tuscany, Coney Street

Unexpectedly I like this place. So much in fact I've been back twice. The decor, although a little predictable is difficult to fault and I think successfully merges the original medieval with a modern bare-wood stainless steel interior. There was a slight mix-up with our booking- which is, in my mind totally unforgivable, especially as I rang up two hours before to change to non-smoking, following the near-miraculous and unsuspected success of my new year's resolution.

Oscar's
